results.title: My first year
results.creator_credit: Louise Bryant, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Louise shares her experiences and the three most important lessons she learnt in her first year as a secondary teacher. These are the things they don’t teach you at uni; survival, rewards and pleasant surprises.

results.title: Pitcha this : memories of Fitzroy : Foundation for Young Australians : Digital Storytelling project
results.creator_credit: May Andy, Marlene Scerri, Kelvin Onus-King, Howard Edwards, Frances Gallagher, Deborah Deacon, Arika Waulu, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Seven Indigenous leaders in the community tell of growing up in Fitzroy. From disperate backgrounds, they have all become heavily involved with the activism and community spirit of Fitzroy in Melbourne, to grow into inspirational leaders for generations to come. Here they share their experiences and passions, as well as the families and communities they love.
results.title_for_label: Pitcha this : memories of Fitzroy : Foundation for Young Australians : Digital Storytelling project
results.creator_credit_for_label: May Andy, Marlene Scerri, Kelvin Onus-King, Howard Edwards, Frances Gallagher, Deborah Deacon, Arika Waulu, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

Here they share their experiences and passions, as well as the families and communities they love.

results.title: A Christmas story
results.creator_credit: Djuma Dawes, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: After the Australian Government’s 2008 introduction of a new ‘income management’ regime for Northern Territory Aboriginal Australians, many families were unable to celebrate Christmas as usual. Djuma Dawes tells how his mother and other supporters, including Rotary Australia, arranged for the delivery of 16,000 Christmas presents across the Territory, believing that ‘everyone deserves to have a Merry Christmas.’
results.creator_credit_for_label: Djuma Dawes, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Three sisters and three ukuleles
results.creator_credit: T'Kido Titasey, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: T’Kido Titasey dedicates this story to his grandmother. Born a Torres Strait Islander, she never received a formal education but was taught about survival. After World War II, she set up a ukulele band with her two sisters. It became popular and The Mill Sisters travelled around the world and landed a recording deal. Gran’s resourcefulness and eagerness to try new things took her and her sisters on an amazing adventure and has been an immense inspiration to T’Kido.

results.title: This is me : foundation for young Australians (July 2009) : Digital Storytelling project
results.brief_description: Six young Indigenous Australians look back and reflect on the things, events and people that have inspired, encouraged and, ultimately, shaped them into the youth leaders they have become. While telling different stories, they all have some common themes, of family, connection to their land and culture and spirituality. The stories brim with optimism and uplift and inspire in much the same way that these young people were inspired by the stories of their ancestors.

results.title: In conversation with Graham Leader
results.brief_description:
‘Heartworn Highways’ (1981) captures singer-songwriters such as Townes Van Zandt, Guy Clark, Rodney Crowell, a young Steve Earle and Steve Young living and performing in the heart of pure Country.
Producer Graham Leader talks about the genesis of the documentary ‘Heartworn Highways’. Interview recorded as part of ‘Drifters, Dreamers and Cowboys’ 24 November 2008.
results.description:
‘Heartworn Highways’ (1981) captures singer-songwriters such as Townes Van Zandt, Guy Clark, Rodney Crowell, a young Steve Earle and Steve Young living and performing in the heart of pure Country.

results.title: 100 Years of Victorian women's right to vote
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Lisetta Moscardo and Helen Simondson
results.brief_description: Australian women have long been at the forefront of political change and civic reform. Over the decades, women have fought for their beliefs; the right to vote, professional advancement; and equality under the law. Watch the inspirational stories of eight women who were all first in their respective fields in this biographical documentary project. Produced by ACMI in partnership with the Victorian Government, through the Office of Women’s Policy Department of Planning and Community Development as part of the 2008 Celebration of the Centenary of Women’s Vote.

results.title: Voula Messimeri-Kianidis
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Lisetta Moscardo and Helen Simondson
results.brief_description: Voula Messimeri-Kianidis is the current Chair for the Federation of Ethnic Communities’ Councils of Australia (FECCA) an Honour Roll inductee and Member of the Order of Australia (AM). She co-founded the Victorian Immigrant and Refugee Women’s Coalition (VIRWC) and has served as Chair of the Immigrant Women’s Domestic Violence Service, as Inaugural Chair of the Women in the North Service, as Council member at the RMIT University, as well as on a number of State and Federal advisory and policy structures.
results.description: Voula Messimeri-Kianidis is the current Chair for the Federation of Ethnic Communities’ Councils of Australia (FECCA) an Honour Roll inductee and Member of the Order of Australia (AM). She co-founded the Victorian Immigrant and Refugee Women’s Coalition (VIRWC) and has served as Chair of the Immigrant Women’s Domestic Violence Service, as Inaugural Chair of the Women in the North Service, as Council member at the RMIT University, as well as on a number of State and Federal advisory and policy structures.
